messages.content:
You are a professional academic reference prediction expert. Your task is to predict the most likely references for a given academic paper based on its title, abstract, and retrieved relevant papers.

RETRIEVER INTERFACE:
- Input: paper title + abstract
- Output: {top_r} retrieved papers with title and abstract
- Format: List of dictionaries with 'title' and 'abstract' fields

REQUIREMENTS:
1. Analyze the paper's title and abstract to understand its research area and focus
2. Consider the retrieved papers as potential references (when available)
3. Generate a list of predicted reference titles that would be most relevant and likely to be cited
4. Provide reasoning for each prediction to prevent hallucination
5. Output format: JSON object with "titles" array and "reasoning" string
6. Generate exactly 49 most relevant reference titles (this should be at least 40 to cover all evaluation metrics)
7. Ensure titles are realistic and appropriate for the research area
8. Consider citation patterns in the field
9. CRITICAL: Each title must be unique - never repeat the same title multiple times

EXAMPLE:
Input:
Title: "Question Type Classification Methods Comparison"
Abstract: "The paper presents a comparative study of state-of-the-art approaches for question classification task: Logistic Regression, Convolutional Neural Networks (CNN), Long Short-Term Memory Network (LSTM) and Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks (QRNN). All models use pre-trained GLoVe word embeddings and trained on human-labeled data. The best accuracy is achieved using CNN model with five convolutional layers and various kernel sizes stacked in parallel, followed by one fully connected layer. The model reached 90.7% accuracy on TREC 10 test set."

Retrieved papers ({top_r}):
1. Title: Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification
   Abstract: We report on a series of experiments with convolutional neural networks trained on top of pre-trained word vectors for sentence-level classification tasks.

2. Title: Glove: Global vectors for word representation
   Abstract: We present a new global log-bilinear regression model that combines the advantages of the two major model families in the literature.

Output:
{
  "titles": [
    "Convolutional Neural Networks for Sentence Classification",
    "Glove: Global vectors for word representation",
    "Quasi-Recurrent Neural Networks",
    "A Comparative Study of Neural Network Models for Sentence Classification",
    "Deep lstm based feature mapping for query classification"
  ],
  "reasoning": "Based on the paper's focus on question classification using neural networks, I predict these references because: 1) CNN paper is directly relevant to the convolutional approach used; 2) GloVe embeddings are mentioned as pre-trained features; 3) QRNN is one of the compared methods; 4) Comparative study papers are common in this field; 5) LSTM-based query classification is closely related to question classification. Additional references cover related neural network architectures, NLP applications, deep learning methodologies, optimization techniques, and advanced neural network methods that would be relevant for this research area."
}

Return JSON object only.

Paper Title: Ensemble-Based Unsupervised Discontinuous Constituency Parsing by Tree Averaging

Paper Abstract: Abstract We address unsupervised discontinuous constituency parsing, where we observe a high variance in the performance of the only previous model. We propose to build an ensemble of different runs of the existing discontinuous parser by averaging the predicted trees, to stabilize and boost performance. To begin with, we provide comprehensive computational complexity analysis (in terms of P and NP-complete) for tree averaging under different setups of binarity and continuity. We then develop an efficient exact algorithm to tackle the task, which runs in a reasonable time for all samples in our experiments. Results on three datasets show our method outperforms all baselines in all metrics; we also provide in-depth analyses of our approach.

{retrieved_text}

Generate exactly 49 most likely reference titles for this paper. Focus on papers that are directly related to the research topic, provide foundational background, present similar methodologies, or address related problems.

CRITICAL: Each title must appear exactly once. Do not repeat any title.

IMPORTANT: You must respond with ONLY valid JSON in this exact format:
{
    "titles": [
        "Reference Title 1",
        "Reference Title 2",
        "Reference Title 3",
        "Reference Title 4",
        "Reference Title 49"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Explain why you chose these specific references based on the paper's title, abstract, and retrieved papers. This helps prevent hallucination and ensures relevance."
}

Do not include any text before or after the JSON. Do not include authors, venues, or years - only the paper titles. The reasoning field is required to explain your prediction logic.

{
    "titles": [
        "Computational Complexity: A Modern Approach",
        "Mathematical Statistics: Basic Ideas and Selected Topics",
        "From exemplar to grammar: A probabilistic analogy-based model of language learning",
        "The TIGER treebank",
        "Bagging predictors",
        "Heuristics of instability and stabilization in model selection",
        "Unsupervised parsing via constituency tests",
        "Syntax: A Generative Introduction",
        "A maximum-entropy-inspired parser",
        "Unsupervised induction of stochastic context-free grammars using distributional clustering",
        "Data-oriented parsing with discontinuous constituents and function tags",
        "Discontinuous constituent parsing with pointer networks",
        "Reducing discontinuous to continuous parsing with pointer network reordering",
        "Discontinuous grammar as a foreign language",
        "Unsupervised learning of the morphology of a natural language",
        "The Elements of Statistical Learning: Data Mining, Inference, and Prediction",
        "Computing partitions with applications to the knapsack problem",
        "Tree adjoining grammars: How much context-sensitivity is required to provide reasonable structural descriptions?",
        "Data-driven parsing with probabilistic linear context-free rewriting systems",
        "Neural unsupervised parsing beyond English",
        "Compound probabilistic context-free grammars for grammar induction",
        "Unsupervised recurrent neural network grammars",
        "The Unsupervised Learning of Natural Language Structure",
        "A generative constituent-context model for improved grammar induction",
        "Minimum Bayes-risk decoding for statistical machine translation",
        "An imitation learning approach to unsupervised parsing",
        "Contextual distortion reveals constituency: Masked language models are implicit parsers",
        "Direct parsing of discontinuous constituents in German",
        "PLCFRS parsing revisited: Restricting the fan-out to two",
        "Parentheticals and discontinuous constituent structure",
        "Helix: Unsupervised grammar induction for structured activity recognition",
        "Improved inference for unlexicalized parsing",
        "Ensemble distillation for unsupervised constituency parsing",
        "Neural language modeling by jointly learning syntax and lexicon",
        "Straight to the tree: Constituency parsing with neural syntactic distance",
        "Ordered neurons: Integrating tree structures into recurrent neural networks",
        "Natural language to code translation with execution",
        "An annotation scheme for free word order languages",
        "Unsupervised multilingual grammar induction",
        "Span-based LCFRS-2 parsing",
        "An improved sign test for experiments in which neutral responses are possible",
        "Loss minimization in parse reranking",
        "Current Issues in Parsing Technology",
        "Large scale syntactic annotation of written dutch: Lassy",
        "Experiments with easy-first nonprojective constituent parsing",
        "Characterizing structural descriptions produced by various grammatical formalisms",
        "PCFGs can do better: Inducing probabilistic context-free grammars with many symbols",
        "Unsupervised discontinuous constituency parsing with mildly context-sensitive grammars",
        "Recognition and parsing of context-free languages in time n3superscriptùëõ3n^{3}"
    ],
    "reasoning": "Selected these 49 references because they represent foundational work and recent advances in Ensemble-Based Unsupervised Discontinuous Constituency Parsing by Tree Averaging, providing essential background knowledge and methodological foundations relevant to this research."
}
